Message.Msg: from the senate joint resolution 1 passed yesterday c) WAR POWERS RESOLUTION REQUIREMENTS- (1) SPECIFIC STATUTORY AUTHORIZATION- Cons istent with section 8(a)(1) of the War Powers Resolution, 50 U.S.C. ยง 1541, et seq. , the Congress declares that this section is intended to constitute specific statutory authorization within th e meaning of section 5(b) of the War Powers Resolution, within th e limits of the aut horization established under this Section. (2) APPLICABILITY OF OTHER REQUIREMENTS- Nothing in this resolution supersedes any requirement of the War Powers Resolution. SECTION 3. LIMITATION. Message.Title: Jobs growth misses high hopes; unemployment rate drops to 7.3%
Message.Msg: Job growth was less than expected in August as the U.S. economy added 169,000 positions, raising questions over whether the Federal Reserve will begin a pullback on its historically easy monetary policy. http://www.cnbc.com/id/101014110

Message.Title: North Carolina Republicans Looking to Ax Income Tax
Message.Msg: The chairman of the North Carolina Senate Finance committee said yesterday that he hopes to use the next legislative session to eliminate the state income tax. Instead the chairman suggests they replace the income tax with a consumption-based sales tax to make up for the lost revenue. Currently, across the country there are seven states that do not have an income tax, and North Carolina could make it eight.

Message.Title: Top Chemical Weapons Expert Highly Skeptical of U.S. Case Against Syrian Government
Message.Msg: Washingtonโs Blog September 6, 2013 Jean Pascal Zanders is widely acknowledged as one of the worldโs top chemical weapons experts, having been quoted in the last two weeks about Syrian chemical weapons by McClatchy, Time, theLos Angeles Times, Post-Gazette, Huffington Post, Der Spiegel, Agence France-Presse, Global Post, theTelegraph, and many other publications. We interviewed Zanders by phone. Q: You were quoted in the Huffington Post on August 30th as saying that the Youtube videos cited by the American government were not conclusive, as you couldnโt tell where or when the videos were taken โฆ or even whether they were from the same incident or different incidents. Do you still hold that view, or have you seen other videos that change your mind? Zanders: No, I have not changed my mind. The general observation still stands, and it will stand until we have the actual report from the U.N. investigation. I do not deny that a chemical with toxic chemicals has taken place. But I am just as concerned about how people are interpreting things in terms of a particular goal โฆ which in this case is military intervention. Living in a democracy we have the rule of of law, and we collect and analyze a variety of evidence collected at certain scenes before passing any kind of final judgment. One of the concerns I have is if we look over the periods starting in March 19th with the major allegation of chemcial weapons use near Aleppo, Syria, everything is being reinterpreted as sarin. When I look at video images that have been going around, what I see is a large number of people suffering from aspyhixia, but only a minority (if the photos are representative of the total picture) display symptoms that would correspond to exposures to neurotoxicants. John Kerry used the term โs

Message.Title: Shouldn'r Congress be Debating a Delcaration of War on Iran?
Message.Msg: WASHINGTONโThe U.S. has intercepted an order from Iran to militants in Iraq to attack the U.S. Embassy and other American interests in Baghdad in the event of a strike on Syria, officials said, amid an expanding array of reprisal threats across the region. Military officials have been trying to predict the range of possible responses from Syria, Iran and their allies. U.S. officials said they are on alert for Iran's fleet of small, fast boats in the Persian Gulf, where American warships are positioned. U.S. officials also fear Hezbollah could attack the U.S. Embassy in Beirut and on Friday the State Department ordered nonessential U.S. diplomats to leave Lebanon because of security concerns.

Message.Title: Eisenhower had the Courage to say No to War Eight Times
Message.Msg: Dwight Eisenhower, possessed the gravitas and courage to say no to war eight times during his presidency. He ended the Korean War and refused to aid the French in Indochina; he said no to his former wartime friends Britain and France when they demanded U.S. participation in the capture of the Suez Canal. And he resisted liberal democrats who wanted to aid the newly formed nation of South Vietnam. We all know what happened after his successor ignored Eisenhowerโs advice.

Topic.Title: Do Any of You Democrats Care that Obama and Hillary Lied About Benghazi?

Message.Msg: I bet all you did was wave a flag too Given the Republican obsession with Benghazi talking points, itโs time for a very specific flashback. In 2008, two non partisan groups released a study that determined that President Bush and his top aides made 935 false statements about the security risk posed by Iraq in the two years following September 11, 2001. These statements were part of a deliberate campaign, according to the study conducted by the Center for Public Integrity and the Fund for Independence in Journalism. They concluded, โThe false statements dramatically increased in August 2002, with congressional consideration of a war resolution, then escalated through the mid-term elections and spiked even higher from January 2003 to the eve of the invasionโฆ In short, the Bush administration led the nation to war on the basis of erroneous information that it methodically propagated and that culminated in military action against Iraq on March 19, 2003.โ The studyโs conclusions were further reinforced when former Bush White House press secretary Scott McClellan wrote, โtop Bush aides had outlined a strategy for carefully orchestrating the coming campaign to aggressively sell the warโฆ In the permanent campaign era, it was all about manipulating sources of public opinion to the presidentโs advantage.โ According to the study, then President George W Bush made 232 false statements about Iraq and former leader Saddam Husseinโs possessing weapons of mass destruction, and 28 false statements about Iraqโs links to al Qaeda. โPresident George W. Bush and seven of his administrationโs top officials, including Vice President #$%$ Cheney, National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice, and Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, made at least 935 false statements in the two years following September 11, 2001, about the national security threat posed by Saddam Husseinโs Iraqโฆ On at least 532 separate occasions, Bush and these three key officials, along with Secretary of State Colin Powell, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz, and White House press secretaries Ari Fleischer and Scott McClellan, stated unequivocally that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction (or was trying to produce or obtain them), links to Al Qaeda, or both.โ On July 2004, the Republican majority led Senate Select Committee released the Intelligence Senate Report on Iraqi WMD Intelligence, which identified numerous failures in intelligence gathering and โanalysisโ (i.e., interpretation). However, Republicans defended the Bush administrationโs statements on Iraq. An investigation into the administrationโs use of the intelligence was delayed for three years due to Republicans claiming it wasnโt as important (Senator Roberts, R-KS) as other pending items. Phase two of the investigation was released in 2007, but not all of the report was released. It determined, โour Committee has concluded that the Administration made significant claims that were not supported by the intelligence.โ

Topic.Title: Has Everything Obama Done been a failure?

Message.Msg: Keeping one's promise is good currency for any politician, and this was a big one that Obama delivered on. The numbers: 4,484 Americans killed, 32,200 wounded, $806 billion spent (with an estimated $1 trillion needed for future medical care for war veterans through 2050, says a Brown University study) โ all for a war that began under a pretext (finding weapons of mass destruction) that never panned out. Instead, it evolved into a costly, 105-month grind that damaged America's image in the world and, it could be argued, strengthened Iran's standing in the region. On top of all this, the war wasn't paid for. Yes, it toppled Saddam Hussein. But other Mideast dictators have been overthrown pretty much on their own during the Arab Spring; historians can only ponder how Saddam might have fared. Obama opposed the war all the way back in 2002 โ and promised repeatedly on the campaign trail in 2008 that he'd end the conflict. Mission accomplished.

Message.Title: Russian warships head to Syria
Message.Msg: Two Russian warships are being dispatched to the Syrian coast as Moscow boosts its presence in the region ahead of expectations the US will not wait for world support and go it alone with air strikes on the Assad regime. The St Petersburg central naval command has announced the large landing warship Nikolai Filchenkov will set sail for the Syrian coast to join two Russian destroyers which had already left.

Topic.Title: Warning: Americans abducted, Obama daughter 'raped'...

Message.Msg: The dominant story about the job market is no longer the nationโs 11.3 million unemployed people or the painfully slow pace of hiring. Itโs the growing portion of the working-age population that has dropped out of the labor force and isnโt even looking for a job. The jobs report for August seemed upbeat on the surface, since the unemployment rate dropped by one-tenth of a point to 7.3%. But analysts have been quick to point out that the unemployment rate fell because the number of people looking for work -- part of the numerator in the equation used to determine the unemployment rate -- declined. Thatโs usually a sign of an ailing economy, not a recovering one! That's the real picture!

Message.Title: Bowing please leave Washington, we need space for our Airbus 320's, we will have 130 of Jet blues planes next door
Message.Msg: ATS to modify Airbus A320s in Everett Aircraft-modification company Aviation Technical Services (ATS) will install broadband satellite Wi-Fi technology on 130 JetBlue A320s at its Paine Field facility.Expect to see some Airbus A320s parked in Boeingโs backyard over the next 18 months. Aircraft-modification company Aviation Technical Services (ATS), based at Paine Field in Everett, announced Wednesday it had won a contract to install broadband satellite Wi-Fi technology on 130 JetBlue A320s. All the installations are expected to be completed by the end of 2014. ATS, has about 1,100 employees in Everett and 50 in a new facility at Moses Lake. .
